body:
Windows only uses file extensions to determine which application should, by default, handle the file. If you have a batch file that you rename to a .txt file. It should always open with Notepad.exe unless you changed the default association in the Default Programs app. This is different from Linux and OS X (where the file extension doesn't matter). I think we are safe to assume .cmd and .bat are always and the only batch files.

As for should we detect, we probably shouldn't because we probably can't come up with a list of all the exceptions. Leave that up to the user to use the correct function. I agree with @rasky that there should be a separate CmdCommand() function and documentation to point to it.
